However, around the time of the Chinese Exclusion Act in the 1890s, the word was applied to all sorts of products (such as bean curd) to indicate a certain type of origin.  Soon it was being used in product advertising to specifically indicate Chinese products.  The result of this was that “Chinaman” began to be used as a derogatory term, to refer to cheap imitations of Chinese goods, although with much less frequency than “Chink”.
